title: 110_hr7298
content: Small business expensing provisions have been made permanent. The small business expensing provisions have been made permanent, with an increase in the expensing limits for equipment and computer software. The limit for equipment has been raised to $500,000 and $1,000,000, while the requirement for computer software to be placed in service before 2011 has been removed. In 2009, the small business expensing limits for equipment and computer software were increased to $500,000 and $1,000,000 respectively. The requirement for computer software to be placed in service before 2011 was removed. Amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 224 introduces a new deduction for the purchase of domestically manufactured automobiles under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The new deduction allows individuals to deduct the cost of qualified automobiles placed in service during the taxable year, with a limit of $10,000 per vehicle. A qualified automobile is defined as a motor vehicle assembled in the US by a manufacturer, with the original use starting with the taxpayer, and acquired for personal use. The term "motor vehicle" refers to a vehicle designed for use on public streets with at least 4 wheels. Special rules include reducing the basis of property for which a deduction is allowed and recapturing deductions if the property is no longer eligible. No deduction is allowed for property used outside the US. No deduction is allowed under subsection (a) for property subject to depreciation allowance under section 167. Additionally, no double benefit is permitted for expenses eligible for deduction or credit under other tax provisions. This section expires after December 31, 2010. Sec. 224 allows a deduction for purchasing domestically manufactured automobiles. Sec. 225 provides a cross-reference. The amendments apply to property placed in service after the enactment date of the Act.
